awd_titl_txt: Tracing the Dynamical States of Intracluster Media (ICMs)
awd_abstract_narration:
The universe has assembled itself by gravity into objects from the size of planets and stars up to galaxies and, on the largest scales, clusters of galaxies. The investigators will focus on understanding the formation of these clusters, giving us important insights into the entire process of how objects form.   Galaxy clusters can contain hundreds of galaxies and are filled with very hot gas - their atmospheres, or "intracluster media". These atmospheres are so hot that most of the light they emit is X-rays that can be seen only from space. Astronomers have established that this hot gas has often been highly disturbed when one cluster violently collides and merges with another cluster. The gas motions can tell us about the collisions and how these largest structures in the universe form. Space X-ray telescopes are limited in their abilities to trace these motions, especially outside the denser cluster centers. As it turns out, however, galaxies scattered throughout clusters spew out streams of highly energetic particles that emit radio waves visible from the earth that reveal their interactions with the intracluster media. The intracluster gas motions can also energize radio emitting particles, illuminating the motions. The investigators will find these radio emissions and map their details, using both new and existing ground based radio telescope observations and utilizing the citizen-science-based "Radio Galaxy Zoo." In addition, they will compute detailed physical models to determine how these emissions can be used to trace out the motions of the intracluster media as well as their origins and histories.  The results of these studies will substantially improve our understanding of how galaxy clusters form.


Galaxy clusters are the largest known gravitationally bound systems in the universe. They are filled with 'intracluster media," diffuse plasmas with temperatures of 10s of millions of degrees, which are visible from space using X-rays.  The investigators will address three key questions about these media:  1) what is the dynamical state of the gas, its flows, turbulence and shocks? 2) how do these dynamical features help us understand the cluster formation process? and 3) how do we reliably connect the underlying motions with what we can observe?   The investigators will specifically concentrate on behaviors observable at radio wavelengths, using emission from electrons moving at relativistic speeds in the presence of a magnetic field.  This allows them to study regimes such as cluster outskirts, for which very little X-ray information is available.  They will carry out numerical simulations at the technical frontier, coupling the magnetohydrodynamics of the hot gas to the relativistic particles generating the radio emission. They will conduct new state-of-the-art radio telescope observations and analyses, along with information from the citizen science project Radio Galaxy Zoo on distortions of radio-emitting plasmas caused by the hot gas flows.   Together, this work will enable the investigators to gain important information about the cluster formation process, a key piece in the universal picture of how structures in the universe develop over billions of years.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: Research supported by this grant developed and applied a powerful combination of frontier computer simulations and radio astronomical observations to define, characterize and trace distinctive and diagnostic structural patterns in the hot, diffuse, and magnetized plasma media that fill galaxy clusters (the cluster ICMs). The ICM dynamical states, especially including such key properties as patterns in their motions, as well as distributions of their temperatures, magnetic fields and very high energy charged particles (cosmic rays), are expected to be products of the formation histories of each cluster, with tell-tale modification and stimulation by internal galaxies and especially by energetic outflows from massive black holes within some of those galaxies (so-called "radio galaxies" when they are illuminated by radio emissions).

Cluster-scale, diffuse radio emissions from cosmic ray electrons spiraling around the ICM magnetic fields are now also increasingly being observed by astronomers, especially by using the vastly increased capabilities of a new generation of radio telescopes just now coming on-line across the globe. The processes that activate and maintain these diffuse radio emissions are likely to derive from and to reflect the underlying dynamics of the ICM and the events that drive those dynamics. Thus, the radio emissions should provide a uniquely valuable probe of ICM dynamics and the physical properties of the ICM itself. Especially since it is now beginning to be possible to examine such radio emissions in some detail throughout many clusters, these emissions offer a new and powerful probe of the very natures of galaxy clusters. That is what motivated this study. On the other hand, some major technical challenges had to be addressed up front to ensure the success of our study.

On the theoretical side, the dynamics and associated underlying physics involved in likely dynamical scenarios within clusters are very complex. Consequently, sophisticated computer simulations of the phenomena being studied become essential tools. Unfortunately, meaningful simulations of this type quickly become prohibitively large-scale and difficult to carry out in practice. To address this challenge, we devoted significant effort to the development of a novel, very high efficiency, high performance computer simulation code that incorporates the needed physics accurately. That enabled us to carry out a substantial number of very large, new and innovative computer simulations using available computational resources that were designed to study distinctive dynamical interactions with radio galaxies. The simulations included both embedded magnetic fields and cosmic ray electrons, so that we were able to compute observable outcomes of the dynamics. Indeed, as we had hoped, these simulations uncovered a number of unexpected, diagnostic dynamical behaviors that now should serve to help isolate and characterize actual events in real clusters. 

Also, as part of our theoretical research, we devoted significant effort into the analysis and interpretation of several previously run large-scale computer simulations designed to follow in some detail the formation of individual clusters as the universe expanded from the Big Bang. Those simulations allowed us to establish several cluster-scale (and larger) structural patterns that appear to strongly restrict the physical properties of diffuse matter that falls into clusters to make their ICMs.

On the observational side, the key radio telescopes and their products are very new, and the needed observations are still quite challenging. Accordingly, our research provided major contributions to technical aspects of such observations as well as essential contributions to increasing the reliability of the physical interpretation of the observations. We also made important contributions to analysis and interpretation of newly obtained radio observations by some of the new telescopes in and around multiple clusters. In the process we discovered a substantial number of never-before-identified dynamical patterns associated with several of the clusters. Those patterns sometimes showed distinctive dynamical relationships with adjacent radio galaxies, possibly revealing physically diagnostic interactions between the ICM and the radio galaxy. Going forward these observations and what they have revealed may represent a brand-new window to deciphering ICM dynamics.

Broader Impact: The research efforts under this grant incorporated meaningful research and outreach mentoring of multiple students ranging from students in high school to undergraduate university students, to graduate university students. Several of those students came from under-represented groups, including those who are female and of color. Each of those students has continued towards a STEM career.

Because the research products included visually striking images, many of which could be combined into animations, the research efforts also naturally enabled important public outreach. In addition, researchers supported by this grant played significant roles in development of a new, popular citizen science effort named "Radio Galaxy Zoo", further expanding the grant impact into the community.
